Pre-Game Insights: Namibia, forced to move all home games after their stadiums in Windhoek were not passed for use in the World Cup qualifiers by the Confederation of African Football, have a 100% record in Group H campaign after their opening two fixtures last November.
Namibia also beat Sao Tome e Principe away in November and so go into the third round of matches top of the table, ahead of favourites Tunisia on goal difference.
Only the group winner will qualify for the 2026 World Cup finals, being co-hosted by Canada, Mexico and the USA.
Namibia coach Collin Benjamin has more pressing concerns, notably over the fitness of his star striker Peter Shalulile, who missed last Saturday’s Nedbank Cup final.

Liberia also benefitted from the FIFA ruling after losing at home to both Malawi and Equatorial Guinea in their opening two qualifiers in Monrovia. But they now have three points, even if their start to the campaign was far from convincing.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Namibia’s star striker Peter Shalulile is injured and unable to participate.
Ananias Gebhardt, a key player for Namibia, has retired from international football.
Ryan Nyambe, a fullback for Namibia, is also injured.
Riaan Hanamub is set to take over as captain for Namibia from Peter Shalulile due to the latter’s injury.
Only eight of Liberia’s 23-man squad are based outside of the country as new coach Mario Marinica has overhauled the team.
It will be the fifth time that Liberia and Namibia meet, with one win apiece and two goalless draws.
